GeneralInformation.History: Founded 1960 as University of Alberta at Calgary, and acquired present status and title 1966
GeneralInformation.AcademicYear: September to June (September-December; January-April; May-June). Also Summer Session (July-August)
AdmissionRequirements: Secondary school certificate or recognized foreign equivalent

GeneralInformation.History: Founded in 1926 as the Alberta College of Art (ACA), the college was originally part of what is now the Southern Alberta Institute of Technology (SAIT). Although the two campuses still border each other, ACA officially separated from SAIT in 1985 to become a stand-alone, independent, publicly funded college of art and design. In 1995 amended its name to become the Alberta College of Art and Design. In 2018, the government of Alberta announced that the college had achieved university status based on the quality of its programs. In 2019, the college received its new name and visual identity as the University of Alberta Arts (AUarts)

Founded in 1921 as the Calgary Bible Institute. Became an accredited university college in 1995 and changed its name in 1999 to Nazarene University College (NUC). In 2003, Canadian Bible College (CBC) and Canadian Theological Seminary (CTS) moved to join NUC on the same campus in 2003, received accreditation in 2004, and changed their name to Alliance University College (AUC). AUC and NUC maintained a close relationship, began offering joint programs in 2006, and were often referred to as Alliance University College-Nazarene University College (AUC-NUC), although the two institutions awarded degrees independently until 2007.In 2007, AUC and NUC formed a single entity called Ambrose University. In 2014, province of Alberta granted 'university' nomenclature to Ambrose - Ambrose University College is renamed Ambrose University

Founded 1970. An open, distance education university funded by the Department of Advanced Education of the government of Alberta. Accepted first students 1973, and received permanent self-governing status under the Alberta University Act 1978
GeneralInformation.AcademicYear: No terms. Admission is granted all year round in undergraduate programmes

GeneralInformation.History: Founded 1907 as Alberta Seventh-day Adventist secondary school. The Board of Trustees authorized the establishment of a junior college 1919. Became known as Canadian Union College and statred offering its first four-year programme in Theology 1947. Acquired present title 1997. Formerly Canadian University College (until 11 December 2015)

Founded in 1921 as Concordia College by the Missouri Synod Lutheran Church. In 1967, Concordia College began offering first-year university courses in affiliation with the University of Alberta. It became a degree-granting university in 1987. In 1995, Concordia College changed its name to Concordia University College of Alberta to reflect its status as a degree granting institution. In 2015, Concordia University College became Concordia University of Edmonton
GeneralInformation.AcademicYear: September to April (September-December; January-April). Also Spring/Summer Session (May-August)
AdmissionRequirements: Secondary school certificate or recognized foreign equivalent, including International Baccalaureate and Advanced Placement

GeneralInformation.History: Founded 1971 as Grant MacEwan College. Acquired present title 2009

Divisions.College: Languages and English as a Second Language

GeneralInformation.History: Founded 1965 as Medicine Hat Junior College. Acquired present title 1969
Founded 1910 as Mount Royal College. Acquired present title 2009
AdmissionRequirements: Secondary school certificate or recognized foreign equivalent; interview for some programmes

GeneralInformation.History: Founded 1963 as Red Deer College (RDC). In 2021, Red Deer College was converted into a regional polytechnic institute called Red Deer Polytechnic
Founded 1916, as the Provincial Institute of Technology and Art (PITA). Renamed the Southern Alberta Institute of Technology (SAIT) 1960. Rebranded as SAIT Polytechnic in 2004
Founded in 1986 under the name of Mark Charlton. Became St. Mary's University College in 2004. Acquired its current status and title of St. Mary's College in 2014
AdmissionRequirements: Secondary school certificate or recognized equivalent

GeneralInformation.History: Founded 1979 as The King's College, an Edmonton's Christian university. Became The King’s University College in 1993. Became The King's University in 2015
AdmissionRequirements: Secondary school certificate with minimum 60% average in prescribed courses or recognized foreign equivalent
Proficiency in oral and written English
If English is applicant's second language, TOEFL score of 580+, or computer-based score of 237+, or IELTS score of 6
Requirements may include acceptable performance in entrance tests, such as ACT and SAT

GeneralInformation.AcademicYear: September to April (September-December; January-April); Spring and Summer sessions available
AdmissionRequirements: Secondary school certificate or recognized foreign equivalent; post secondary transcrits; English language proficiency
Secondary school certificate or recognized foreign equivalent, with 65% or equivalent average (actual cut-off may vary from year to year depending on space available and demand)
